RelatedSentence: Serbian authorities have ordered the urgent evacuation of 12 villages and towns along the raging Sava River , including one where soldiers , police and volunteers have been working around the clock to protect the country 's main power plant .

A2: for half of Serbia and most of Belgrade
RelatedSentence: The coal - fired Nikola Tesla plant , which supplies electricity for half of Serbia and most of Belgrade , lies in the flood - hit town of Obrenovac , 16 miles upstream of the capital .
Emergency crews have so far defended the power plant by building high walls of sandbags but it is not clear whether those will withstand the force of an upcoming river surge .

At least 35 people have died in five days of flooding caused by unprecedented torrential rain .
Entire towns and villages are underwater , thousands of hills have crumpled into landslides and tens of thousands have been forced to flee their homes .
The situation in Obrenovac is critical , said Predrag Maric , a Serbian emergency official .
The Sava flood wave is expected to reach Obrenovac and Belgrade later today and peak by Wednesday .
Some 7,800 people have already been evacuated from the town , where many homes are completely submerged by water .

In Bosnia , Foreign Minister Zlatko Lagumdzija called the flood damage immense and compared it to the carnage during the country 's 1992-95 war that killed at least 100,000 people and left millions homeless .

Floods have also triggered more than 3,000 landslides across the Balkans .
Aside from sweeping away home and barns , the landslides have carried land mines left over from the region 's war , along with their warning signs , to entirely new , often unknown , locations .
Landslides and land mines devastated very fertile land , Mr Lagumdzija said .
